dublin_core.dcvalue: Non communicable diseases NCDs are the leading cause of disease burden in most countries and are projected to be responsible for an even greater proportion of years of life lost over the next 2 decades 1 According to Global Burden of Disease study estimates ischemic heart disease cerebrovascular disease and diabetes ranked 1st 2nd and 12th respectively as causes of disability adjusted life year DALY loss in 2016 2 Depressive disorders were ranked 17th on the list 2 In 2015 the most important risk factors for DALY loss globally were high systolic blood pressure followed by smoking high fasting plasma glucose and high body mass index with non optimal blood pressure being the leading contributor to disease burden in all but the lowest income countries 3 In September and October 2018 respectively two global health meetings reminded us if this was needed about the challenges and opportunities around combatting NCDs at a global level The first was the Third UN High Level Meeting on NCDs which produced a Political Declaration considered by many as grossly inadequate but nonetheless allowed member states to reaffirm a commitment to meeting NCD targets over the coming years 4 The second was the Global Conference on Primary Health Care on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of the historic Alma Ata declaration An expected endorsement of the Declaration of Astana will highlight the critical need to transform some of the major successes from vertical disease focused programs e g for maternal and child health and certain infectious diseases to the delivery of comprehensive integrated care through high quality primary care services across the life course addressing major global health threats including NCDs 5 Such primary healthcare strengthening is considered a crucial pillar to achieving universal health coverage a key target in the Sustainable Development Goals aimed at ensuring that everyone has access to effective health services without exposure to financial hardship 6
